objectives: Improve the dog's ability to maintain attention and focus on the owner

steps: Hold a treat near your eyes to get the dog's attention.
Once the dog makes eye contact, reward it with the treat and praise.
Repeat this process, gradually increasing the duration of eye contact before giving the reward.
Place a low-value treat on the ground in front of the dog.
Cover the treat with your hand and say 'leave it.'
When the dog looks away from the treat and focuses on you, reward it with a higher-value treat and praise.
Increase the difficulty by using higher-value treats or introducing distractions.
Start walking with your dog on a leash.
Periodically stop and ask for eye contact or a sit from your dog.
Reward your dog with treats and praise for complying and maintaining focus during the walk.
Play games like 'wait' or 'stay' where the dog must control its impulses and maintain focus.
Start with short durations and gradually increase the difficulty and duration of the games.
Reward the dog with treats and praise for successfully following the commands.
Introduce controlled distractions during training sessions, such as toys, noises, or other dogs.
Practice maintaining the dog's focus and obedience commands amidst the distractions.
Reward the dog for maintaining focus and responding to commands even in challenging situations.
